abstract.text: Creates a Hermitean-to-real fast Fourier transform operation and returns the result tensor.

inlineContent.text: A complex-valued input tensor with reduced size (see Discussion). Must have datatype
A tensor of rank one containing the axes over which MPSGraph performs the transformation. See
A descriptor that defines the parameters of the Fourier transform operation - see
This operation computes the fast Fourier transform of a complex-valued input tensor according to the following formulae.

code: output[mu] = scale * sum_nu exp( +/- i * 2Pi * mu * nu / n ) in'[nu], where

inlineContent.text: , for the last dimension defined by
is out of range of the input dimension.
is the volume of the transformation defined by the dimensions included in
and the sum is done separately over each dimension in
dimension length of that axis. With this API MPSGraph treats the input tensor to have only the unique
frequencies, which means that the resulting tensor has size
in the last dimension defined by
is the size of the input
in the last transformed dimension and
Currently MPSGraph supports the transformation only within the last four dimensions of the input tensor. In case
you need to transform higher dimensions than the last four, you can tranpose the higher dimensions of the input
to be within that last four and then transpose
the result tensor back with the inverse of the input transpose.

abstract.text: Build, compile, and execute compute graphs utilizing all the different compute devices on the platform, including GPU, CPU, and Neural Engine.
The optimized representation of a compute graph of operations and tensors.
Creates a Hermitean-to-real fast Fourier transform operation and returns the result tensor.
Creates a fast Fourier transform operation and returns the result tensor.
Creates a permutation operation and returns the result tensor.
The class that defines the parameters for a fast Fourier transform (FFT) operation.
A parameter which controls how graph rounds the output tensor size for a Hermitean-to-real Fourier transform.
The scaling mode of the fast fourier transform (FFT) operation.
The symbolic representation of a compute data type.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
